bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, February 3, 1875

div1.p: Reed writes that he misses her. Reed's step-mother is in Norfolk and may visit Murfeesboro - Emilie Lawrence's hometown. He has received his commission from Army Medical Corps.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, February 3, 1875
div1.p:
In your last
letter you were speaking of the delight-
ful spring-like weather that prevailed
at Murfreesboro, and it made me
sigh once more for that dear old
town. Just to think that while it is
almost impossible for us to keep
warm, although we have four blaz-
ing fires in the house, that you
are able to spend your evenings
in pleasant promenades & star-
gazings- That while we shrink in-
doors from a wind blowing at
the rate of sixty miles an hour and
a temperature 13° below zero, you sit
at your open window, aiding the gen-
tle breeze with a palm leaf fan.
Oh! my! how I should like to exchange
lots with you! Ah! what have I
said! Pardon me, my darling, I didn't
intend to say that I should like
for you to be exposed to these bit-
ing winds, oh! no! only that I would
like to hold a palm leaf in my
hand and fan your sweet brow-
Now wouldn't that be too charming!
At the same time to discourse on
pleasant topics, interspersed with
words of affection -- from my lips, of
course. On second thought, I wouldn't
have to say anything, since you have
so many things to tell me. Can a
body imagine any situation more
delightful than to sit by his darling
little sweetheart & listen to pleas-
ant words as they fall from her
sweet lips? If there is any condition
that conveys more happiness, I, for
one, don't want to hear of it. I'm a-
fraid it would be too great a tax on
my heart- I know I should never
live to tell of it- What! more pleas-
ant than to listen to the tones (oh!
these tone of that voice, can I ever, for
a moment, forget it?) of my own
little Em's voice? Away with you!
and know that not all the choirs
of this world could draw me from
the sound of her voice!!

You perceive, my darling, that the
above remarks were addressed to an
imaginary person who dared tell
me that I could find more pleas-
ure elsewhere, than by your side;
and you see how quickly I order-
ed him from my presence. Indeed 'twere
fortunate for him that he was
purely imaginary, for had he been
present in the body, I am inclined
to think that I should have laid
violent hands on him! All things con-
sidered, it's well that I didn't meet him!
I received a letter from Ma, yesterday,
and from the general tenor of her
remarks, I imagine that she is
not over-pleased with Norfolk
City life. It is so different from the
quiet ways of her valley home that
she finds some difficulty in ac-
commodating herself to the ways &
customs of that little city. I think,
however, that this will soon wear
away, and I do not doubt but that
she will at last, regret when the time
arrives for her to return to the
mountains- She spoke of a trip to
Murfreesboro, but did not say when
she would go- Since you say that
if we are both in Murfreesboro, at
the same time, you will not so much
as even looks at me, and since the
object of my trip to Murfreesboro
is that you, & no other, shall look
at me (am growing a mustache for
that very purpose), I will write to
my mother, at once, & beg her, either
to make haste her visit, or delay it
till after I have been looked at-
I didn't think, my darling, that you had
rather see my mother than myself-
Well, never mind, when I come to Mur-
freesboro, I am going to talk to a
certainly elderly lady & not to you-
What do you think of that? Ain't you
sorry that you said so?
You will remember that I wrote you
that there was some danger of Con-
gress reducing the number of the
Medical Corps, & that I would might
thereby lose my position -- Well that
danger has passed -- The number of
Assistant Surgeons will be reduced
from 150 to 125, but as I am no. 112
that won't affect me- Indeed, I have
just seen, by yesterday's paper, that
all of my class have been commis-
sioned by the Senate. So you perceive
that there is not escape for you but
to join the Army.
div1.closer:
Adieu, my own
sweet love. Ever, your fond and
devoted Walter.
